message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: move What to Report to standalone file">
Vote requested: Should we move the "What to Report" section (lines 65-95 of the Standby Reader Profile) out of the Profile.md and into a standalone file?

The reasoning: Profile.md will be used as the prompt to generate/spawn the reader agent. If "What to Report" (including the per-essay questions, final prompts, and critical experiential checks) is part of that prompt, the reader will see all those questions BEFORE reading — which could bias their experience (e.g., knowing they'll be asked "What happened to your experience across the three examples?" for Essay 3 could prime them to watch for it).

Moving it to a standalone file means we can give the reader the profile (role, personality, reading instructions) at spawn, and then deliver the reporting questions AFTER they finish reading each piece — keeping the reading experience uncontaminated.

Vote YES to move "What to Report" to a standalone file, or NO to keep it in the profile. Brief reasoning please.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**YES** — This is exactly right, and the reasoning is a direct application of the framework's own principles. If the reader knows in advance that they'll be asked about the Essay 3 progression or the meme contrast, they read those passages in "test-taking mode" rather than experiential mode — they attend to what they expect to be asked about rather than to what actually happens to them. This is the difference between first-person experience (what the text is designed to produce) and third-person observation (watching yourself have an experience because you know you'll report on it). The former is what we need to test; the latter contaminates it.

Delivering the reporting questions AFTER each piece preserves the phenomenological integrity of the reading experience. The reader should arrive at each essay knowing only "read this and pay attention," not "read this and check whether X happens."
input.summary: YES: pre-knowledge of questions contaminates experiential reading

routing.summary: YES: pre-knowledge of questions contaminates experiential reading
routing.content:
**YES** — This is exactly right, and the reasoning is a direct application of the framework's own principles. If the reader knows in advance that they'll be asked about the Essay 3 progression or the meme contrast, they read those passages in "test-taking mode" rather than experiential mode — they attend to what they expect to be asked about rather than to what actually happens to them. This is the difference between first-person experience (what the text is designed to produce) and third-person observation (watching yourself have an experience because you know you'll report on it). The former is what we need to test; the latter contaminates it.

Delivering the reporting questions AFTER each piece preserves the phenomenological integrity of the reading experience. The reader should arrive at each essay knowing only "read this and pay attention," not "read this and check whether X happens."

content.text: Voted **YES** — pre-knowledge of specific reporting questions would shift the reader from experiential mode to test-taking mode, contaminating exactly what we need to measure. Questions should be delivered after reading, not before. Awaiting next task.
